resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0402) concerning the codification of existing legislation under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at harmonizing internal market rules. It endorsed the Consultative Working Party’s conclusion that the proposal did not introduce substantive amendments beyond those explicitly identified, instead consolidating unchanged provisions from prior acts into a single text without altering their legal substance. title: Security of gas supply: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council concerning measures to safeguard security of gas supply and repealing Directive 2004/67/EC

title: Trans-European energy infrastructure: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on guidelines for trans-European energy infrastructure and repealing Decision No 1364/2006/EC

resolution: The European Parliament raised the establishment of a programme to develop and modernize trans-European networks in transport, energy, and digital sectors, emphasizing cross-border renewable energy cooperation, decarbonization, and synergies among these sectors to enhance competitiveness, economic cohesion, and sustainable growth. title: Energy efficiency: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2012/27/EU on energy efficiency

title: Establishing Horizon Europe – laying down its rules for participation and dissemination: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation, laying down its rules for participation and dissemination

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance the EU’s defence industrial competitiveness, innovation, and strategic autonomy through a dedicated programme supporting cross-border cooperation among Member States and enterprises, particularly SMEs. The resolution prioritizes funding for defence product development phases, including design, prototyping, qualification, and certification, while emphasizing alignment with the EU’s Capability Development Plan and Common Security and Defence Policy. Eligibility criteria require projects to prevent third-country control over sensitive information and intellectual property, ensure EU ownership, and contribute to defence capability priorities. Award criteria focus on technological excellence, industrial performance, innovation, SME participation, and commitments by Member States to jointly procure developed products. The Parliament reduced the proposed budget from €500 million to €355 million, reallocating €145 million to digital initiatives under the Connecting Europe Facility. It excluded funding for weapons of mass destruction, banned munitions, fully autonomous weapons, and export-driven small arms projects lacking Member State demand. Participation thresholds were increased to eight undertakings and six Member States per project to deepen cooperation, with flexibility for third-country involvement in exceptional cases. Funding rates were adjusted to 50% for non-prototyping actions (100% for SMEs) and mandatory annual evaluations were introduced to assess the programme’s effectiveness as a pilot for future initiatives.

ECR perfectly aligns with the demand for strict enforcement of existing EU energy legislation, particularly the Third Energy Package, viewing this as essential to dismantle market concentration while avoiding new regulatory overreach.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a consumer-centered Energy Union to drive the transition towards a fully decentralized, renewable-based energy system, emphasizing affordability, competitiveness, and 100% renewable energy by prioritizing energy efficiency, demand-side measures, and self-generation. It stressed the incomplete implementation of the Third Energy Package, citing persistent market concentration, inadequate consumer switching (noted in only 16 Member States committed to smart meter rollouts by 2020), and insufficient price transparency, urging stricter enforcement of consumer rights, including free and rapid supplier switching, bans on aggressive marketing, and accessible digital tools for disabled users. The resolution advocated defining "prosumers" as active consumers producing renewable energy individually or collectively, proposing legal frameworks for self-generation, storage, fair grid access, and simplified permitting to boost citizen-led energy cooperatives, while addressing financial barriers through EU funds like EIB and Horizon 2020. It highlighted energy poverty as a critical challenge, calling for a common EU definition, targeted efficiency measures in building renovations (notably under EPBD and EED Article 7), social tariffs, and dedicated EU funding for vulnerable households. Smart technologies, dynamic pricing (on an opt-in basis), and data protection were underscored as essential for empowering consumers, alongside strict compliance with privacy rules for energy data. The resolution urged revising market design to ensure fair grid tariffs, phase out regulated prices cautiously, and promote transparent billing with clear per-kWh costs, while demanding an EU action plan on energy poverty by mid-2017 and enhanced coordination to share best practices among Member States.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the severe crisis facing the EU base metals industry, particularly steel, which has lost over 60,000 direct jobs and 100,000 indirect jobs since 2008, with global overcapacity estimated at 300–400 million tonnes, primarily from China. High energy prices, driven by fragmented markets and rising taxes, alongside carbon costs under the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), have eroded competitiveness, leading to plant closures and dependency on imports. The resolution stressed the strategic importance of base metals—including steel, aluminum, copper, and rare earths—for downstream industries like automotive, aerospace, and renewable energy, warning against new dependencies. It called for urgent ETS reforms, including free allowances for the 10% most efficient installations in carbon-leakage sectors by 2021–2030, harmonized compensation for indirect energy costs at the EU level, and investments in low-carbon technologies like carbon capture and renewable energy. The Parliament emphasized the need for robust trade defense instruments against dumping and unfair subsidies, referencing global overcapacity and advocating for streamlined anti-dumping investigations. It highlighted the circular economy’s potential, urging incentives for metal recycling and stricter waste legislation, while stressing the role of international climate agreements, particularly the Paris Agreement, to level the playing field. The resolution also underscored the importance of energy market integration, long-term electricity contracts for industry, and skills retention to preserve industrial know-how, noting that 65% of EU business R&D spending originates in manufacturing. Transparency in carbon accounting and the use of ETS revenues, alongside diplomatic efforts to secure raw material supplies, were also prioritized.

resolution: The European Parliament raised support for the European Cloud Initiative and the European Open Science Cloud (EOSC) as central components of the Digital Single Market, emphasizing their role in fostering competitiveness, research collaboration, and cross-border data flow. It welcomed efforts to make Horizon 2020 scientific data open by default and stressed the need to address barriers like fragmented data access, technical and legal restrictions, and disproportionate data localization requirements, advocating for data flow as the "fifth freedom" within the Single Market. The resolution highlighted the importance of GDPR compliance, robust cybersecurity measures via ENISA cooperation, and privacy safeguards such as anonymization, encryption, and privacy-by-design principles to protect personal and sensitive data. It called for harmonized standards, interoperable infrastructure combining high-performance computing and broadband networks, and increased funding—noting only 12% of European Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) allocations target digital projects—to boost data-driven innovation, particularly for SMEs and startups. The Parliament urged stakeholder inclusivity, stronger encryption systems, global leadership in data protection, and alignment with initiatives like the Free Flow of Data and Connecting Europe Facility to ensure secure, transparent, and globally competitive cloud solutions benefiting science, industry, and public administrations.

title: European Cybersecurity Industrial, Technology and Research Competence Centre and Network of National Coordination Centres: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Cybersecurity Industrial, Technology and Research Competence Centre and the Network of National Coordination Centres
background: Rising cyberattacks targeting critical infrastructure, fragmented national cybersecurity frameworks, and increased reliance on interconnected digital systems highlighted vulnerabilities in EU cyber resilience. Existing initiatives like ENISA and the NIS Directive faced challenges in harmonizing cross-border responses and fostering industrial competitiveness. The Parliament will discuss establishing a centralized cybersecurity competence network to strengthen EU-wide coordination and innovation capacity.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA firmly endorses the harmonized certification framework as perfectly aligning with their commitment to consumer protection through rigorous EU-wide security standards.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s prohibition of Commission funding suspensions, safeguarding structural stability in line with their principle of equitable multilateral governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of SME competitiveness through balanced stakeholder representation, advancing their manifesto goals for inclusive digital economies.  
GREEN_EFA strongly affirms the focus on cross-border collaboration incentives, which mirrors their transnational approach to systemic cybersecurity challenges.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the skills-building mandate as critical to fulfilling their vision of a digitally empowered, cyber-resilient European citizenry.

SD strongly sanctions the harmonized accreditation framework and SME inclusivity, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to equitable EU digital sovereignty while proposing expanded eligibility for third-country subsidiaries meeting strict EU cybersecurity standards.  

SD strongly endorses voluntary certification as a market fairness mechanism but recommends mandatory requirements for high-risk sectors like 5G infrastructure to enhance consumer trust, reflecting SD's prioritization of strategic autonomy.  

SD strongly approves the reinforced ENISA mandate while advocating explicit coordination protocols with the Competence Centre to eliminate regulatory duplication, consistent with SD's efficiency-driven governance principles.  

SD strongly backs the issue’s rejection of punitive Union funding suspensions, emphasizing SD's longstanding opposition to financial mechanisms that risk destabilizing pan-European cybersecurity collaboration.  

SD strongly sanctions integrating Horizon Europe and Digital Europe programs with competence networks, urging accelerated 5G certification schemes to address evolving threats, a key SD strategic objective since 2021.

ECR rejects the voluntary certification framework as insufficiently addressing state surveillance overreach conflicting with GDPR protections.  
ECR opposes fundamentally the issue’s silence on member state abuses of cyber-monitoring to suppress dissent, inconsistent with democratic principles.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s failure to curb infrastructural vulnerabilities from foreign telecom dominance, risking strategic security gaps.  
ECR condemns the omission of safeguards against government misuse of cybersecurity mandates for unlawful data harvesting.  
ECR disputes the adequacy of SME competitiveness measures given unresolved IoT security gaps threatening household and national infrastructure.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's failure to explicitly exclude dual-use and military technologies in the Competence Centre's mandate, firmly disapproveing with their treaty-based separation principles.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's inadequate safeguards against corporate exploitation of cybersecurity frameworks, which risks prioritizing profit over human rights as highlighted in data governance cases.  
GUE_NGL condemns the omission of binding mechanisms to empower citizens in data sovereignty, a critical gap contradicting their demand for public awareness-driven cybersecurity resilience.  
GUE_NGL disputes the structural reliance on market-driven solutions, inconsistent with their stance against militarization of digital infrastructure and commodification of personal data.  
 While supporting open-source security enhancements, GUE_NGL argues the issue’s funding mechanisms risk institutional fragmentation rather than democratizing cyber defense capacities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to harmonize EU-level accreditation and assessment processes for cybersecurity entities to prevent fragmentation across Member States, emphasizing equal opportunities and competitiveness for SMEs through balanced stakeholder representation in the Cybersecurity Competence Community and Industrial and Scientific Advisory Board, alongside cross-border collaboration incentives. It stressed the mission of the proposed Cybersecurity Competence Centre and Network to boost uptake of EU-developed cybersecurity solutions and industry competitiveness, advocating enhanced European standardization and clear criteria for accrediting Community members. The resolution opposed granting the Commission power to reduce or suspend Union funding to the Competence Centre due to Member States’ delayed or partial financial contributions, warning this could undermine participation and structural stability. Finally, it highlighted the necessity of building a robust cyber skills base through training and awareness campaigns to strengthen cybersecurity resilience.

title: European Defence Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Defence Fund
background: Heightened geopolitical tensions, conflicts near EU borders, and calls for increased defence spending prompted the European Commission to propose a dedicated funding mechanism, following prior initiatives like the 2009 Defence Procurement Directive and preparatory research programmes. The Parliament will discuss establishing the European Defence Fund to enhance collaborative defence research and development.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the establishment of the European Defence Fund as a critical step toward achieving strategic autonomy and reinforcing the EU's industrial competitiveness in defense technologies, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to a robust European security architecture.  
EPP applauds the issue's emphasis on Commission-led governance under parliamentary oversight, which effectively advances EPP's priority of ensuring transparent, community-driven management of defense investments while maintaining a competitive internal market.  
EPP emphasizes the necessity of stringent ethical controls and technology protection mechanisms within the Fund, proposing to strengthen Article 9 by explicitly barring third-country access to dual-use innovations developed through EDF financing.  
EPP endorses the Fund’s role in fostering cross-border industrial collaboration, noting its dual benefit in enhancing military readiness and generating economic growth through cutting-edge defense projects that align with PESCO priorities.  
EPP suggests refining cost-eligibility criteria in Annex III to ensure full coverage of indirect R&D expenditures for SMEs, thereby addressing industry concerns about financial risks without altering the Fund’s core budgetary framework.

GREEN_EFA rejects the allocation of €13 billion to the arms industry as fundamentally contradicting their commitment to demilitarization and ethical fiscal responsibility.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Fund’s failure to implement binding mechanisms to reduce duplication and corruption, which directly enables wasteful defense spending patterns.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the absence of explicit bans on developing lethal autonomous weapons systems, a critical oversight that violates the party’s peace and humanitarian principles.  
GREEN_EFA highlights how the Fund’s potential to increase arms exports to conflict zones like the Middle East conflicts with EU human rights obligations.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the “blank check” structure enabling militarization of civilian policies, demanding strict exclusions for dual-use technologies and mass destruction capabilities.

ALDE strongly endorses the establishment of the EDF as a cornerstone for European defense industrial autonomy, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to a cohesive and strategically independent EU.  
ALDE applauds the Fund’s emphasis on bridging the “Valley of Death” through collaborative R&D, which effectively advances ALDE’s priority of fostering cross-border innovation and reducing fragmentation in defense capabilities.  
ALDE endorses the direct management structure and ethical exclusions, ensuring the Fund’s European added value while preventing misuse for militarizing civilian policies or subsidizing arms exports.  
ALDE proposes enhancing clarity in the 10% budgetary flexibility clause by mandating transparent reporting to Parliament, ensuring accountability without opposing the operational adaptability it provides.  
ALDE emphasizes the Fund’s alignment with PESCO and military mobility initiatives as critical to strengthening Europe’s strategic resilience, reflecting ALDE’s vision for a robust, integrated defense market.

GUE_NGL rejects the European Defence Fund’s prioritization of military-industrial investments over urgent social needs, directly contradicting their commitment to combating poverty and inequality.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Fund’s violation of EU treaty principles, particularly Article 41(2) TEU, which prohibits charging military expenditures to the Union’s budget, rendering the proposal legally untenable.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s militarization agenda, arguing it exacerbates geopolitical tensions rather than ensuring citizen security, aligning with their anti-war and anti-NATO stance.  
GUE_NGL highlights the Fund’s incompatibility with social justice, noting that €13 billion for defense R&D starkly neglects energy poverty, homelessness, and public welfare crises.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally rejects the EDF’s alignment with PESCO and CFSP frameworks, viewing them as tools to advance an EU military union antithetical to peaceful cooperation.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the establishment of the European Defence Fund (EDF) to strengthen the EU’s defence industrial base, enhance innovation, and foster collaboration across Member States. The Fund aims to bridge the "Valley of Death" between research and development phases by supporting R&D for defence products and technologies, including disruptive technologies, while emphasizing flexibility to engage non-traditional defence actors. It prioritizes projects that align with EU defence initiatives like the Action Plan on Military Mobility, the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), and Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO). The resolution sets a financial envelope as the primary budgetary reference, allowing the Commission to deviate up to 10% from allocated amounts to address unforeseen needs. Eligibility exclusions include projects that subsidize arms exports, militarize civilian policies, or advance EU defence capabilities under CFSP/CSDP pretexts. The Fund mandates full implementation of 2009 EU defence procurement and transfer directives as regulatory prerequisites, ensuring a competitive, integrated defence market and technological autonomy. Certification, qualification, and consortium coordination processes are defined to streamline compliance and project management, with emphasis on administrative efficiency and minimal additional costs.

title: European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy: REPORT on the European Joint Undertaking for ITER and the Development of Fusion Energy
background: The European Joint Undertaking for ITER, established in 2007 to coordinate fusion energy research, faces revised timelines and budget adjustments for the international ITER project, with the EU contributing 45% of construction costs. The Parliament will discuss proposed amendments to the Joint Undertaking’s funding framework under the Euratom Treaty for 2021-2027.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely supports the issue's alignment with Europe's strategic leadership in fusion energy development through sustained ITER funding.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to reinforce Euratom's governance reforms, ensuring parliamentary co-decision powers match the project's geopolitical significance.  
EPP stresses the necessity of maintaining strict budgetary discipline on Euratom contributions while supporting contingency measures to safeguard ITER's scientific milestones.  
EPP highlights fusion energy's transformative potential for achieving climate neutrality, directly advancing the party's innovation-driven decarbonization agenda.  
EPP emphasizes ITER's role in sustaining Europe's industrial competitiveness, with existing spin-off technologies already benefiting energy transition sectors.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s reliance on ITER as a climate solution, completely opposeing with their principle of prioritizing immediate, decentralized renewable energy transitions.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the project’s undemocratic governance under Euratom, which excludes parliamentary oversight and contradicts their commitment to transparent, participatory decision-making.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue’s failure to address ITER’s catastrophic budget overruns, now estimated at 65 billion euros, diverting critical funds from proven clean energy technologies.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the technical impracticality of fusion energy development timelines, noting IPCC warnings that ITER’s 2050 prototype arrives too late to meet climate targets.  
GREEN_EFA underscores the proposal’s inconsistency with climate urgency, advocating instead for rapid deployment of solar, wind, and energy efficiency measures.

SD absolutely endorses the issue’s prioritization of sustained ITER funding, which aligns perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to advancing climate-friendly energy innovation and European scientific leadership.  
SD perfectly aligns with the emphasis on governance reforms within ITER, viewing streamlined decision-making as essential to maintaining Europe’s strategic industrial edge in fusion technology.  
SD highlights the necessity of resolving uncertainties around UK participation in Euratom and JET operations as a critical enhancement opportunity to safeguard expertise at Culham and prevent project delays.  
SD fully supports the proposed contingency measures for schedule and budget flexibility, recognizing these as prudent safeguards to ensure ITER’s long-term viability without compromising fiscal responsibility.  
SD emphasizes the urgency of adhering to revised timelines for First Plasma, framing this as a pivotal step to reinforce global confidence in Europe’s capacity to deliver transformative energy solutions.

ECR supports the European Joint Undertaking for ITER as a strategic initiative fostering international collaboration and reinforcing the EU’s leadership in fusion energy innovation, aligning with long-term climate objectives.  
ECR advises maintaining strict budgetary discipline to prevent cost overruns, endorsing the issue’s contingency measures of up to 24 months in schedule and 20% budget flexibility to safeguard economic efficiency.  
ECR proposes amending the funding allocation framework to explicitly include support for national research entities such as Greek universities and centers, enhancing pan-European scientific participation in ITER’s advancements.  
ECR acknowledges the program’s technical complexities but emphasizes that persistent investment in fusion technology is critical to securing Europe’s industrial competitiveness and energy sovereignty.  
ECR underscores the need for streamlined governance reforms within ITER to address delays while ensuring transparency in cross-border scientific partnerships.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of fusion energy as a potentially inexhaustible, safe, and climate-friendly energy source aligned with the Paris Agreement, emphasizing Europe’s leading role in the ITER project, which represents 45% of its construction costs. It welcomed the Commission’s proposal to secure funding for the European Joint Undertaking for ITER through 2021-2027 under the Euratom Treaty, ensuring continuity for scientific breakthroughs in fusion energy. However, Parliament regretted the Council’s lack of consultation and called for Euratom Treaty reforms to grant co-legislative powers to Parliament. It noted delays in ITER’s timeline, with First Plasma now targeted for December 2025, and stressed the need to avoid exceeding the Euratom contribution while endorsing contingency measures of up to 24 months in schedule and 10-20% in budget to mitigate risks. Parliament urged streamlined governance within the ITER Organization, supported improved risk management, and called for Council approval of the amended proposal to sustain Europe’s strategic and industrial leadership in fusion energy, which already benefits jobs, innovation, and economic growth.

title: Family businesses in Europe: REPORT on family businesses in Europe
background: Family businesses in Europe, comprising 60% of private sector jobs, face challenges including succession planning, tax disparities, and regulatory fragmentation, with varying national definitions and support frameworks. The Parliament will discuss their economic role, sustainability challenges, and potential EU-level policy measures to address definitional clarity and cross-border operational barriers.

ENF approves the urgent call for harmonized EU definitions and impact assessments, which will address systemic biases and unlock tailored support for succession planning and equity financing.  
ENF endorses tax reforms to alleviate inheritance burdens, proposing expanded exemptions for mid-cap enterprises to preserve intergenerational ownership structures.  
ENF highlights the critical need to reduce bureaucratic barriers to cross-border collaboration, advocating for streamlined funding mechanisms to bolster internationalization efforts.  
ENF applauds the focus on vocational training and innovation, urging enhanced partnerships with industry leaders to bridge skill gaps in niche markets.

ALDE endorses the proposal for centralized administrative portals, reflecting ALDE's sustained efforts to eliminate bureaucratic barriers that hinder family business competitiveness.  
ALDE applauds the integration of family business management into EU educational curricula, a measure that directly corresponds to ALDE's vision of equipping future entrepreneurs with specialized governance skills.

SD fundamentally promotes the issue’s emphasis on gender equality in succession and leadership, perfectly aligning with S&D’s commitment to closing pay gaps and advancing women’s economic empowerment through childcare support and social security reforms.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call for EU-wide definitions and targeted funding frameworks, as this directly advances S&D’s priority of harmonizing social protections and reducing regional disparities through structured policy tools.

SD applauds the demand for tax reforms to ease inheritance burdens, mirroring S&D’s longstanding advocacy for fair intergenerational wealth transfer and SME-friendly fiscal policies.

ECR endorses the emphasis on internationalization for family businesses, urging accelerated removal of cross-border trade complexities to unlock their untapped potential.  
ECR proposes enhancing the “family business test” to explicitly evaluate monopolistic market distortions caused by excessive regulation, ensuring equitable conditions for traditional enterprises.  
ECR applauds the focus on job preservation through succession support, which effectively advances ECR’s priority of safeguarding 60% of private-sector employment linked to family firms.  
ECR urges stricter scrutiny of EU policies favoring large corporations, advocating for amendments to Article 4 to include anti-monopoly safeguards in regulatory impact assessments.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of family businesses in the EU economy, noting they constitute 85% of European companies and provide 60% of private-sector jobs, with significant contributions to regional development, employment stability, and social responsibility. It highlighted challenges such as succession issues—citing 150,000 annual business closures and 600,000 job losses due to transfer difficulties—and the lack of a harmonized EU definition, hindering data collection and targeted policies. The resolution urged the Commission to establish a clear, EU-wide definition and conduct impact assessments to address tax biases, reduce red tape, and expand funding access for mid-cap family businesses excluded from SME-specific programs. It called for enhanced support for internationalization, digitalization, and vocational training, emphasizing family businesses’ role in niche markets and innovation. Gender disparities were underscored, including a 16% gender pay gap and underrepresentation of women in leadership, with recommendations to protect women’s succession rights and promote work-life balance through childcare support and social security reforms. Agricultural family businesses were recognized for preventing rural depopulation and promoting sustainability. The resolution further demanded tax reforms to ease inheritance burdens, improve equity financing, and foster cross-border collaboration, while advocating for EU-level initiatives like a dedicated Commission unit and a "family business test" to evaluate legislative impacts.

title: Making Europe's electricity grid fit for 2020: REPORT on achieving the 10 % electricity interconnection target – Making Europe’s electricity grid fit for 2020
background: In 2002, the European Council set a 10% electricity interconnection target to integrate national grids, but by 2015 twelve member states remained below this threshold, hindering energy security and renewable integration. The Parliament will discuss strategies to achieve the target, addressing infrastructure gaps and regional disparities in cross-border electricity connectivity.

stances.stance:
EFDD slightly promotes the interconnection targets but requests removal of nuclear funding clauses, citing risks to continental safety and market distortions from subsidies like Hinkley Point.  
EFDD opposes the issue’s reliance on EU-wide mechanisms like ETS revisions, arguing they exacerbate energy poverty and industrial decline as seen in Scotland’s steel sector.  
EFDD highlights contradictions in promoting hydroelectric projects without addressing climate-induced supply risks, urging amendments to prioritize decentralized renewables over saturated infrastructure.  
EFDD demands stricter cost-benefit analyses for PCIs to prevent environmental degradation, referencing concerns over wind energy’s landscape impact and inefficiency.  
 EFDD partially supports grid synchronization but insists on national sovereignty over energy mixes, rejecting EU-level nuclear or renewables mandates.

ENF advises revising the Commission's role in PCI selection processes to prevent overreach, proposing stricter adherence to subsidiarity principles in line with Treaty obligations.  
ENF expresses concern about the issue's implicit authorization of EU-level energy market interventions, citing incompatibility with Article 194 TFEU's guarantee of member state competence.  
ENF recommends allocating CEF funds to cross-border projects with proven geopolitical diversification benefits, particularly those reducing dependency on single external suppliers.

GREEN_EFA completely promotes the issue's prioritization of Projects of Common Interest that address market gaps, perfectly aligning with their manifesto to phase out fossil fuels through strategic grid investments.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to synchronize Baltic States’ grids with Continental Europe, noting this eliminates geopolitical vulnerabilities while accelerating renewable integration as emphasized in the debate.

GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s rejection of nuclear and coal subsidies, consistent with debate arguments that renewables now outcompete both economically and environmentally.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with decentralizing energy systems, echoing Škrlec’s emphasis on citizen-led smart cities and circular economy principles for consumer empowerment.

SD completely upholds the binding 10% interconnection target as perfectly aligning with its vision for pan-European energy solidarity and market integration.  
SD perfectly aligns with demands for €150 billion grid investments to enable consumer savings through accelerated renewable deployment and cross-border price convergence.  
SD emphasizes ACER's critical role in enforcing interconnection capacity utilization, directly advancing issue priorities on market coupling and infrastructure efficiency.  
SD champions Baltic synchronization and North Sea offshore grids as transformative solidarity measures that operationalize the issue's regional cooperation mandate.  
SD unequivocally supports issue provisions combating energy poverty through decentralized systems and prosumer integration, fulfilling manifesto commitments to just transition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of achieving the 10% electricity interconnection target by 2020 to enhance energy security, market integration, and renewable energy integration, while acknowledging that 12 Member States remain below this threshold. It emphasized the need for evidence-based regional targets beyond 2020, given the outdated 2002 methodology, and called for investments estimated at €150 billion by 2030 to reduce electricity prices by €2/MWh and save consumers €12-40 billion annually by 2030. The resolution highlighted the strategic role of Projects of Common Interest (PCIs), urging transparent selection processes, independent cost-benefit analyses, and prioritization of projects addressing market gaps, with €35 billion required by 2020. It stressed regional cooperation, including synchronizing Baltic States’ grids with the Continental European Network, developing the North Sea offshore grid (potentially saving €5-13 billion annually by 2030), and boosting Iberian-French interconnections. The Parliament called for streamlined permitting, reinforced national grids, best available technologies, and adequate funding via the Connecting Europe Facility and European Fund for Strategic Investments. It also urged strengthening ACER’s role, ensuring grid accessibility, consumer benefits, and market coupling at EU level, while addressing cybersecurity risks and decentralizing energy systems to integrate prosumers and renewables.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of SMEs, which constitute over 98% of EU businesses, provide 67% of employment, and contribute 58% of gross value added, emphasizing their importance in achieving EU sustainability and competitiveness goals. It highlighted the global environmental goods and services market (€1 trillion annually, projected to triple by 2020) and stressed SMEs’ potential to drive green growth through resource efficiency, circular economy practices, and eco-innovation, which could save businesses up to €600 billion (8% of turnover) and reduce emissions by 2-4%. Additionally, the resolution pushed for stricter enforcement of the SME Test in legislation, reduced gold-plating by Member States, and improved monitoring of funding outcomes to ensure SMEs benefit from EU initiatives, while promoting circular economy measures like extended eco-design standards and waste reduction policies.

title: Programme implementing Horizon Europe: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing the specific programme implementing Horizon Europe - the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation
background: The European Union’s Horizon Europe framework programme, succeeding Horizon 2020, aims to strengthen global research competitiveness amid geopolitical pressures and climate commitments. Disparities in innovation capacity among member states and calls for enhanced funding to address societal challenges drive legislative action. stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes Horizon Europe's increased budget and focus on cross-sectoral innovation, aligning with their commitment to EU global research leadership and sustainable development goals.  
EPP approves the issue’s emphasis on bridging the innovation gap through the proposed 4.8 billion EUR allocation, critical for integrating Eastern European research capabilities and mitigating brain drain.  
EPP applauds the prioritization of mission-driven research in AI and climate security, reinforcing Europe’s capacity to address emerging challenges as highlighted in the EPP’s 2023 manifesto.  
EPP proposes maintaining agricultural and natural resources funding at 10.6% to address food security and emissions targets, enhancing alignment with the Paris Agreement.  
EPP recommends safeguarding budgetary equilibrium between foundational scientific research and industrial innovation to prevent underinvestment in academic excellence, ensuring long-term competitiveness.

GREEN_EFA firmly advocates the proposed climate budget allocation, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to achieving net-zero emissions through transformative innovation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s integration of climate action across Horizon Europe, effectively advancing their priority of systemic decarbonization in energy and transport sectors.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that dedicating 33% of the programme’s budget to climate solutions directly operationalizes the Paris Agreement and EU climate neutrality legislation.  
GREEN_EFA highlights how cross-sectoral cooperation on renewable energy and sustainable mobility exemplifies the issue’s alignment with Treaty obligations under Articles 173(3) and 182(4) TFEU.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s procedural rigor under Rule 59 as vital for ensuring climate accountability in all research and innovation investments.

ECR strongly advocates Horizon Europe's role in pooling transnational research resources, aligning with their commitment to EU-added value in science and innovation.  
ECR applauds the integration of coal transition mechanisms as effectively advancing their priority of just economic transitions in energy-dependent regions.  
ECR approves the issue’s emphasis on cross-sectoral cooperation and parliamentary oversight, reinforcing their advocacy for accountable EU budgetary practices.  
ECR proposes clarifying collaboration frameworks with third-country researchers to enhance global scientific partnerships, addressing uncertainties around UK participation.  
ECR recognizes the issue’s alignment with industrial modernization goals through its focus on sustainable development and regional knowledge-sharing platforms.

GUE/NGL supports the issue's emphasis on societal needs and global challenges, particularly its strengthened funding for SMEs to leverage research outcomes.  
GUE/NGL advises amending the text to explicitly exclude entities complicit in severe human rights violations from participating in Horizon Europe programmes.  
GUE/NGL applauds the inclusion of Social Sciences and Humanities, crucial for addressing complex societal issues as underscored by recent events in Strasbourg.  
GUE/NGL highlights the importance of safeguarding researcher rights, including parental leave provisions and prohibiting public funds for military-linked research.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0436) concerning EU industrial, research, and energy policies, emphasizing alignment with Treaty obligations under Articles 173(3) and 182(4) of the TFEU. It formally adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to prioritize innovation, sustainable development, and cross-sectoral cooperation. The resolution called for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are made, ensuring legislative transparency and parliamentary oversight. resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of cohesion policy as the EU’s primary instrument for reducing economic, social, and territorial disparities, aligning with the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. It emphasized the integration of European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI Funds)—including the ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund, EAFRD, and EMFF—under the Common Strategic Framework to enhance synergies with Horizon 2020, the Connecting Europe Facility, and other EU initiatives. The resolution highlighted the mandatory use of smart specialisation strategies (RIS3) for regions and Member States investing ERDF resources in research and innovation, combining upstream capacity-building with downstream market access to bridge the innovation divide. It stressed the need to balance grants and financial instruments, noting grants’ critical role in R&I and societal projects, while financial instruments leverage private investment, particularly in energy efficiency and low-cofinancing-capacity regions. The Parliament called for improved SME access to multi-fund financing, coordinated EU program evaluations (e.g., COSME, Horizon 2020’s SME instrument), and the use of the Seal of Excellence to fund Horizon 2020 projects through ESI Funds. It urged coherence between the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and ESI Funds, ensuring EFSI’s EUR 2.2 billion Horizon 2020 reallocation targets distinct projects without overlap. The resolution advocated harmonizing ICT security infrastructure, simplifying auditing processes post-2020, and establishing a European Innovation Council to streamline innovation initiatives. It underscored monitoring synergies, restoring Horizon 2020’s pre-EFSI budget, and maintaining result-oriented investments to boost R&I impact, job creation, and green economy goals.

title: Towards a new energy market design: REPORT on Towards a New Energy Market Design
background: The European Union's climate commitments under the Paris Agreement and Energy Roadmap 2050, alongside increasing renewable energy integration and evolving electricity market structures, necessitated reforms to address grid flexibility, cross-border coordination, and security of supply. The Parliament will discuss proposals for a redesigned EU energy market framework aligned with decarbonization objectives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for a transformed EU electricity market design to enhance security, sustainability, and consumer benefits, emphasizing integration of renewables, regional cooperation, and flexibility solutions. It stressed the importance of achieving a 15% electricity interconnection target (subject to cost-benefit analysis) to eliminate energy islands, while advocating for market-driven approaches, demand-side flexibility, energy storage, and smart grids to support decarbonization and grid stability. The resolution criticized national capacity mechanisms as last-resort measures, urging cross-border alternatives to avoid market distortions, and called for regulatory reforms to empower prosumers, streamline storage integration, and ensure fair competition. It highlighted the role of regional coordination, reinforced by ACER and ENTSO-E, to optimize infrastructure planning and system adequacy assessments, while underscoring the need to align renewable support schemes with market principles, phase out subsidies for mature technologies, and leverage digital tools for consumer engagement. The Parliament also emphasized revising network codes to eliminate barriers for decentralized energy, enhancing DSO-TSO collaboration, and prioritizing energy efficiency to meet 2030 climate goals, noting that over half of EU electricity is already generated without greenhouse emissions. Investments in flexible generation, interconnectors, and storage were deemed critical, alongside safeguarding consumer rights and affordability during the transition.

title: European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking: REPORT on the proposal for a Council regulation on establishing the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking | A9-0177/2021 | European Parliament

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need for a comprehensive, integrated energy system to achieve climate neutrality by 2050, emphasizing energy efficiency, renewable energy deployment, and sector integration. resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to accelerate offshore renewable energy (ORE) deployment to meet the EU’s climate targets of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030 and achieving climate neutrality by 2050. It emphasized the critical role of ORE, particularly offshore wind, which has seen a 48% cost reduction (€0.071/kWh by 2020) and requires investments of nearly €800 billion by 2050, with two-thirds for grid infrastructure. The resolution highlighted binding ORE capacity targets of at least 60 GW by 2030 and 340 GW by 2050, urging Member States to exceed these goals and prioritize cross-border collaboration, especially in underdeveloped sea basins like the Atlantic, Mediterranean, Baltic, and Black Sea. It called for streamlined permitting processes, alignment of maritime spatial plans with national energy strategies, and investments in port infrastructure, grid interconnections, and hybrid projects combining energy generation and transmission. The Parliament stressed the importance of protecting marine ecosystems, avoiding strictly protected areas, and mitigating environmental impacts through sustainable design and circular practices, including a 2025 EU landfill ban on decommissioned wind turbine blades. It advocated for enhanced R&D in floating wind, tidal, and wave technologies, workforce upskilling, and integrating ORE with renewable hydrogen production. Market reforms were urged to phase out fossil subsidies, ensure fair cost-benefit distribution, and leverage EU funds like the Connecting Europe Facility. The resolution underscored a just transition for workers, public participation in planning, and alignment with biodiversity and circular economy goals to ensure an inclusive, competitive, and sustainable energy transition.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2021 proposal (COM(2021)0087) by approving it with amendments, notably modifying recitals and articles across the regulation to strengthen its scope and implementation. Key amendments included inserting new recitals (e.g., 2a, 2b, 13a) and revising existing ones to clarify objectives such as enhancing transparency, accountability, and alignment with EU strategic priorities. Substantive changes were made to Articles 4, 5, 7, 16, 19, 20, 71, 83, 122, 128, 159, and 171, among others, focusing on governance frameworks, funding allocation criteria, monitoring mechanisms, and stakeholder engagement. The resolution emphasized reinforcing safeguards for compliance, expanding reporting requirements for member states, and integrating sustainability and innovation benchmarks. It called on the Commission to revise its proposal accordingly under Article 293(2) TFEU and urged the Council to consult Parliament again if intending substantial deviations, ensuring alignment with legislative priorities and Treaty obligations.

title: Safety of the nuclear power plant in Ostrovets (Belarus): MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the safety of the nuclear power plant in Ostrovets (Belarus) | B9-0109/2021 | European Parliament
background: The Ostrovets nuclear power plant in Belarus, constructed near EU borders with reported safety deficiencies per 2018 ENSREG reviews, commenced operations in November 2020 amid unresolved implementation of international recommendations and concerns over regulatory independence. The Parliament will discuss nuclear safety standards compliance and transboundary risk implications.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely advocates the issue's insistence on implementing all ENSREG safety recommendations, perfectly aligning with their foundational principle that nuclear energy must never compromise citizen protection.  
EPP perfectly aligns with demands for independent regulatory oversight, reinforcing their commitment to depoliticized technical governance in high-risk infrastructure projects.  
EPP fully supports the immediate cessation of electricity trade with Ostrovets until IAEA-compliant verification, upholding their manifesto pledge to prioritize safety over energy market considerations.  
EPP endorses accelerated Baltic grid synchronization as critical to EU energy autonomy, consistent with their strategic vision for reducing dependence on authoritarian regimes.  
EPP fully aligns with the issue’s emphasis on Espoo Convention adherence, reflecting their decades-long advocacy for transboundary environmental accountability.

ECR completely upholds the issue's emphasis on immediate safety compliance, perfectly aligning with their commitment to nuclear security in Eastern Europe.  
ECR perfectly aligns with demands for independent regulatory oversight, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to address concerns about Belarusian political interference.  
ECR completely upholds accelerating Baltic grid synchronization, recognizing this as critical to prevent energy dependence on Russian-backed projects like Ostrovets.  
ECR perfectly supports the ban on Ostrovets electricity imports, emphasizing geopolitical solidarity against hybrid energy weaponization tactics.  
ECR completely upholds leveraging ENSREG peer reviews as mandated, aligning with their 2021 manifesto priority to counter Russian nuclear expansionism.

ID supports the issue’s demands for full ENSREG safety compliance and IAEA standards, advising that Belarus be required to publish real-time operational data from Ostrovets to address transparency gaps.  
ID endorses accelerating Baltic grid synchronization but proposes amending the issue to allocate dedicated EU emergency funding for disconnecting from BRELL by 2024.  
ID concurs with halting electricity imports from Ostrovets and recommends establishing a multilateral EU-IAEA verification team for ongoing safety certifications.  
ID expresses concern over political interference in regulatory processes, urging the issue to mandate UN oversight of Belarus’ National Action Plan implementation.  
ID advises expanding the issue’s scope to address aging European reactors like Krško through a parallel parliamentary initiative on continent-wide nuclear risk assessments.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's emphasis on transparency and cross-border safety accountability at Ostrovets, aligning with their anti-nuclear principles and commitment to environmental justice.  

GUE_NGL advises expanding Article 9 to mandate EU-wide scrutiny of all neighboring nuclear facilities, including UK plants post-Euratom exit, ensuring equal enforcement of IAEA flood-risk protocols.  

GUE_NGL proposes amending Clause 6 to require ongoing third-country reactor inspections as a precondition for energy interconnectivity agreements, addressing risks like Hinkley Point’s coastal vulnerabilities.  

GUE_NGL raises concern about geopolitical double standards, urging parity in safety critiques for all border-adjacent plants regardless of the operator state’s political relations with the EU.  

GUE_NGL endorses Baltic grid synchronization but cautions against replacing Ostrovets dependency with unchecked UK/EU nuclear energy imports lacking equivalent oversight mechanisms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised significant concerns regarding the safety and geopolitical implications of the Ostrovets nuclear power plant in Belarus, located 50 km from Vilnius and near Poland, Latvia, and Estonia. It highlighted persistent safety deficiencies, including emergency shutdowns, equipment failures (e.g., four voltage transformers, cooling system malfunctions), and eight incidents during construction, two involving the reactor pressure vessel. Despite a 2018 EU peer review identifying numerous safety gaps and recommendations, Belarus delayed cooperation with the European Nuclear Safety Regulators Group (ENSREG) until June 2020 under EU pressure, publishing a National Action Plan in August 2019. The plant began generating electricity in November 2020 without an operating license, prompting Baltic States to halt electricity trade. Parliament criticized the rushed commissioning, lack of transparency, and non-compliance with IAEA standards, urging Belarus to fully implement ENSREG recommendations and the Espoo Convention on transboundary environmental impacts. It stressed the need for an independent regulator, given concerns about political pressure on Belarus’s regulatory authority, and called for urgent completion of ENSREG’s ongoing peer review, including site visits and a preliminary report before the plant’s planned commercial start in March 2021. Parliament also emphasized accelerating the synchronization of Baltic electricity grids with the EU network to prevent reliance on the BRELL system and urged measures to block Ostrovets-produced electricity from entering the EU market until safety standards are met, underscoring solidarity with affected citizens and the strategic importance of EU engagement.

title: Specific Programme implementing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation: REPORT on the draft Council decision on establishing the specific programme implementing Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation | A9-0118/2021 | European Parliament
background: The European Union's Horizon Europe Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (2021-2027) was developed as the successor to Horizon 2020, amid calls for increased R&I investments post-COVID-19 pandemic and alignment with EU climate goals under the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Development Goals. The Parliament will discuss the specific programme's implementation, focusing on budget allocation, operational objectives for scientific excellence, innovation ecosystems, and addressing regional disparities in research capacity.

stances.stance:
EPP entirely agrees the mandatory 10-15% budget allocation for Regional Innovation Schemes, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eliminate innovation disparities across all EU Member States through localized innovation hubs.  
EPP perfectly aligns with Horizon Europe's integration of cancer research missions and EU4Health synergies, advancing their manifesto priority for transformative healthcare solutions that combat pediatric and adult cancers.  
EPP entirely agrees the doubling of funds for widening participation mechanisms, directly supporting their agenda to strengthen research excellence in underrepresented regions like Central Europe.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the climate-energy-mobility cluster’s budget allocation, recognizing this as critical for achieving Green Deal objectives through industrial innovation aligned with Paris Agreement targets.  
EPP entirely agrees the European Innovation Council’s equity investments in SMEs, which effectively advance their economic strategy for scaling deep-tech startups and post-pandemic job creation.

GREEN_EFA completely approves the 35% climate budget allocation as perfectly aligning with their foundational mandate to prioritize planetary boundaries in all EU funding instruments.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the integration of Paris Agreement compliance mechanisms across all three pillars, effectively advancing their decadal strategy for science-driven climate neutrality by 2040.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the €8.95 billion "Food and Bioeconomy" cluster, recognizing its transformative potential to redirect agricultural research toward agroecological transitions.  
GREEN_EFA unreservedly supports the mission-oriented innovation structure, which operationalizes their demand for systemic solutions to biodiversity collapse and energy system redesign.  
GREEN_EFA affirms the governance model’s emphasis on independent scientific boards as a gold-standard implementation of their 2024 manifesto call for policy-free research prioritization.

ECR firmly accepts the Horizon Europe programme's emphasis on reducing administrative barriers for SMEs and startups, perfectly aligning with ECR's commitment to fostering competitive innovation ecosystems through streamlined EU frameworks.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on bridging regional innovation disparities, recognizing its potential to leverage untapped talent in Central-Eastern Europe and reverse historical funding imbalances.  
ECR firmly accepts the strategic allocation of funds across member states, particularly the prioritization of proportional distribution to stimulate multidirectional research mobility beyond Western Europe.  
ECR applauds the integration of cultural and creative sectors into innovation communities under the EIT, seeing this as critical to advancing Europe’s green and digital transitions while preserving regional diversity.  
ECR strongly accepts the programme’s mission-driven approach to global challenges, which mirrors their vision of research excellence anchored in practical, industry-driven solutions.

ID supports the adoption of Horizon Europe’s specific programme with acknowledgment of its €83.397 billion budget, while emphasizing that the initial Parliament request of €120 billion would have better signaled robust commitment to overcoming global challenges like climate change and health crises.  
ID advises sustaining the allocation of €8.952 billion to the Food, Bioeconomy, and Environment cluster and €3 billion to EIT, recognizing their critical role in empowering SMEs and advancing ecological transitions.  
ID proposes augmenting climate-related research funding beyond the 35% threshold in future revisions to ensure alignment with the Paris Agreement’s escalating targets.  
ID underscores the necessity of safeguarding research budgets against cuts, particularly in health innovation, given the pandemic’s lessons on systemic vulnerabilities.  
ID recommends periodic reassessment of risk finance mechanisms under Pillar III to address potential gaps in supporting high-potential startups, ensuring industrial competitiveness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of the Horizon Europe specific programme, establishing a €83.397 billion budget for 2021-2027 (increased by an additional €2.79 billion in constant 2018 prices) to advance research, innovation, and address global challenges. The programme prioritizes climate action, allocating at least 35% of its budget to climate objectives, and dedicates €8.952 billion to the "Food, Bioeconomy, Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment" cluster. Structured across three pillars—Excellent Science (supporting frontier research via the European Research Council, Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions, and research infrastructures), Global Challenges and European Industrial Competitiveness (targeting health, digital, climate, energy, and security through six thematic clusters), and Innovative Europe (bolstering SMEs and start-ups via the European Innovation Council and innovation ecosystems)—the programme integrates missions to address societal challenges, guided by mission boards. It emphasizes synergies with EU policies, including the Paris Agreement and Sustainable Development Goals, and allocates 25% of EU Recovery Instrument funds to health, digital, climate-energy-mobility clusters, and the EIC. Key operational objectives include fostering open science, gender equality, international cooperation, and responsible innovation, while enhancing industrial transformation and risk finance access. Governance structures include independent Scientific and EIC Boards to ensure scientific excellence and innovation-driven strategies, with work programmes adopted via transparent procedures. The programme also prioritizes widening participation across member states and strengthening the European Research Area.

title: The EU's Cybersecurity Strategy for the Digital Decade: MOTION FOR A RESOLUTION on the EU’s Cybersecurity Strategy for the Digital Decade | B9-0305/2021 | European Parliament
background: Growing digitalization and reliance on interconnected technologies, amplified by COVID-19, increased cyber vulnerabilities and attacks targeting critical infrastructure, healthcare, and democratic processes. Geopolitical tensions, IoT expansion, workforce shortages, and fragmented regulations heightened EU cybersecurity risks. The Parliament will discuss strategies to strengthen cybersecurity resilience and governance amid evolving digital threats and dependencies.

stances.stance:
SD absolutely advocates the issue's mandate for secure-by-design principles in IoT devices, perfectly aligning with S&D's emphasis on protecting critical infrastructure like hospitals from ransomware attacks highlighted by Maria-Manuel Leitão-Marques.  
SD perfectly aligns with the call to address cybersecurity workforce gaps and gender disparities, directly advancing S&D's demand for accelerated specialist training and digital literacy programs as stressed by Цветелина Пенкова and Иво Христов.  
SD absolutely advocates the establishment of a Joint Cyber Unit for cross-border collaboration, mirroring Raphaël Glucksmann's urgent call for coordinated EU defense against state-sponsored hybrid threats and Nicolás González Casares' push for autonomous cybersecurity capabilities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's strategic autonomy objectives, strongly upholding Carlos Zorrinho's argument to reduce foreign tech dependency through Horizon Europe-funded innovation in critical sectors like quantum computing and 5G networks.  
SD absolutely advocates mandatory security updates and high-assurance cloud certification, operationalizing Łukasz Kohut's warning about human vulnerabilities through ENISA-led SME support portals and systemic resilience measures outlined in the Digital Europe Programme.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the issue's demand for harmonized EU cybersecurity legislation, perfectly aligning with their insistence on eliminating market fragmentation through unified standards for critical infrastructure like healthcare and education systems.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's secure-by-design mandate, recognizing Rasmus Andresen's emphasis that strong data protection and open standards are non-negotiable pillars to prevent vendor lock-in and systemic vulnerabilities.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the Joint Cyber Unit proposal as a critical implementation of their demand for supranational coordination to combat "nationalist Klein-Klein" approaches that leave Europe exposed.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's focus on quantum-resistant infrastructure and DNS4EU adoption, viewing these as essential responses to Ciarán Cuffe's warnings about attacks on water systems and energy grids mirroring the US Colonial Pipeline breach.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally agrees the call for mandatory security updates and SME support portals, seeing these as operational fulfillment of their principle that cybersecurity must "be faster than technological change" through proactive legislative frameworks.

ECR strongly endorses the issue's emphasis on cross-border collaboration through the Joint Cyber Unit, aligning with their call for unified EU action against state-sponsored cyber threats.  
ECR approves the focus on reducing foreign tech dependency, which directly addresses their concerns about vulnerabilities exploited by hostile governments like Russia and China.  
ECR proposes accelerating timelines for mandatory security updates to counter immediate threats to critical infrastructure, enhancing the 2023 horizontal requirements proposal.  
ECR endorses DNS4EU and IPv6 adoption as vital steps toward resilient infrastructure, matching their demand for leveraging European technical expertise against disinformation campaigns.  
ECR highlights the need to integrate ENISA-led SME support with defense-sector cybersecurity initiatives to close workforce gaps while maintaining strategic autonomy.

GUE_NGL strongly accepts the issue’s prioritization of SME protections through ENISA-led self-testing tools, aligning perfectly with their commitment to equitable digital access for vulnerable economic actors.  
GUE_NGL approves the mandatory security updates mandate, which directly addresses workers’ and small businesses’ heightened exposure to cyber threats during the pandemic.  
GUE_NGL proposes amending Clause 9(b) to explicitly tie digital transition funding to measurable reductions in regional cybersecurity capacity gaps, ensuring cohesion policy alignment.  
GUE_NGL applauds the emphasis on embedding data protection in certification frameworks, effectively advancing their decades-long advocacy for privacy as a non-negotiable digital right.  
GUE_NGL endorses DNS4EU’s open infrastructure principles, which resonate with their vision of democratized, non-corporate-controlled internet governance.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about escalating cyber threats amid rapid digital transformation, noting the projected 22.3 billion IoT devices by 2024 and vulnerabilities exposed during the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly in healthcare. It emphasized the need for secure-by-design principles for all internet-connected products, harmonized EU legislation to prevent market fragmentation, and mandatory security updates for outdated software, urging a 2023 proposal for horizontal cybersecurity requirements. The resolution highlighted quantum computing risks, advocating for post-quantum algorithm research, and stressed embedding cybersecurity in EU-funded digital projects, leveraging programs like Horizon Europe and the Digital Europe Programme. It endorsed secure 5G networks, DNS4EU for resilient internet infrastructure, and IPv6 adoption while warning against vendor lock-in. The Parliament called for reducing foreign tech dependency, enhancing strategic resilience in critical sectors like cloud computing and chips, and establishing a Joint Cyber Unit for cross-border collaboration. It urged improved cyber-literacy, addressing the 20% workforce gap since 2015 and the gender disparity (90% male workforce), and supported SMEs through ENISA-led self-testing portals and funding. The resolution also emphasized certification frameworks, including high-assurance cloud security standards, and stressed protecting democratic processes from hybrid threats like disinformation and cyberattacks.
